results.title: Battleship Potemkin (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This renowned Soviet feature portrays the mutiny aboard the Russian battleship Potemkin and the role of the sailors and citizens of the Port of Odessa in the abortive revolution of 1905. An epic dramatisation, it brought to the attention of the world the theories of Sergei Eisenstein, his emphasis on montage, stress on intellectual content and his treatment of the mass instead of the individual as protagonist.

results.title: Battleground
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Dore Schary and William Wellman
results.brief_description: It is the dead of winter and GIs are dug in near the strategic crossroads of Bastogne. They are surrounded, outnumbered and bombarded with a steady barrage of incoming fire. Ammunition is low and it looks as if the fog will never lift. The Germans, sensing victory, demand surrender - and receive a strong reply from the American commander. Winner of the Best Screenplay and Best Cinematography Academy Awards, this movie is a landmark portrait of triumph under fire dedicated to the honour all soldiers and resonates with the humour, fear and bravery of civilian soldiers put to the test in the greatest conflict the world has ever known.

results.title: Battle scars: an overview of our defence against disease
results.creator_credit: East Australian Film Corporation, VEA and Bob Hardie
results.brief_description: This program investigates the Human immune system and what defences the human body has against disease. Topics covered in this area include: physical barriers against disease, means of pathogenic entry into the body, defences of the body against entry of pathogens, antigens and antibodies, role of phagocytes, the immune system and its function, the nature of immunity, vaccines and their development and the function of antibiotics.

results.title: Battle royale (Collector's edition) [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Battle Royale Production Committee, Sato Masao, Okada Masumi and Kinji Fukasaku
results.brief_description: Based on Koshun Takami’s novel “Shockwave”, Kinji Fukasaku’s controversial “Battle Royale” is a heady mix of violence and satire, which has drawn many comparisons to Kubrick’s “A Clockwork orange”. Not surprising, given that both films have sparked debates regarding the nature of cinema violence and its affects, while offering up an apocalyptic vision of the not too distant future. At the dawn of the new millennium Japan is teetering on the brink of chaos. Unemployment is at an all-time high and youth violence is spiralling out of control. The solution? The Battle Royale Act, a brutal government initiative which requires a randomly chosen group of teenage students to be taken to a deserted island where they must fight each other to the death. The sole survivor of the contest will become an example to Japanese youth of the extremes the government is prepared to go to in order to restore order. With its tongue firmly planted in its cheek, “Battle Royale” taps into the zeitgeist of Japanese society’s biggest fears and secret desires, as we watch in unflinching detail Japanese teenagers hack, shoot, poison and bludgeon each other to death. Warning: Some scenes may disturb. Cast includes: Takeshi Kitano, Aki Maeda, Tatsuya Fujiwara and Taro Yamamoto.

results.title: Battle of the road
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Australian Road Safety Council, Hugh Alexander and Bern Gandy
results.brief_description: Begins by showing the destruction of human life in wartime from modern weapons of war, and then stresses the need to prevent “the battle of the roads” which causes comparable casualties in peace time. The film points out common driving mistakes made by motorists, and shows how the carelessness of pedestrians also causes many accidents. The effects of speed upon the time to brake cars is shown. The huge loss of production each year and the heavy financial burden on the nation due to accidents is emphasised.

results.title: Battle of Kerzhenets
results.creator_credit: Soyuzmult Film Studio, Ivan Ivanov-Vano and Yuri Norstein
results.brief_description:
This animated film illustrates the battle of Kerzhenets and the struggle of the Russian people against foreign invaders. Using Russian frescoes and miniatures from the 14th to 16th centuries, the animators reconstruct the images in order to depict the bloody and violent encounters of war as well as the town’s sorrow for the fate of many soldiers. After the battle the townsfolk regenerate - sow seeds in the field, build new boats, as the blacksmith toils at creating sickles for harvesting. In the final moments, bread is broken and children play in a display of hope and innocence. Set to the music of a Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov opera, “Tale of the Invisible City Kitezh”, the film ably illustrates animator Yuri Norstein’s burgeoning talent, working with his mentor, Ivan Ivanov-Vano.

Credits: Directors, Ivan Ivanov-Vano, Yuri Norstein ; music, Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov ; animator, Ivan Ivanov-Vano.

results.title: Battle of Britain
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Harry Saltzman, S Benjamin Fisz Productions and Guy Hamilton
results.brief_description: This film recreates the greatest air battle in history, when the outnumbered British Royal Airforce battled and fought off the powerful German Luftwaffe at the beginning of World War II. For this film more than 100 vintage aircraft were assembled to re-enact the historic battle in the skies over England. Stars Michael Caine, Trevor Howard, Curt Jurgens, Kenneth More, Ralph Richardson.
